giant-impact-llsvps.title: GEOPHYSICS: GIANT IMPACT ORIGIN OF LLSVPS
giant-impact-llsvps.subtitle: Understanding Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces through Giant Impact Theory
giant-impact-llsvps.content: Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs) are massive structures in Earth's lower mantle that have puzzled scientists for decades. Our research investigates the hypothesis that these features originated from ancient giant impact events during Earth's early formation.

sections.title: Research Overview
sections.content: We employ numerical modeling and seismic analysis to understand how giant impacts during Earth's accretion could have created the observed LLSVP structures. Our models suggest that impact-generated material could have settled in the lower mantle and persisted for billions of years.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.content: Our approach combines high-resolution numerical simulations of giant impacts with seismic tomography data analysis. We use advanced computational techniques to model the long-term evolution of impact-generated heterogeneities in the mantle.

sections.title: Key Findings
sections.content: Our research provides compelling evidence that LLSVPs could indeed be remnants of ancient giant impacts, offering new insights into Earth's early bombardment history and mantle evolution.

integrate-thermodynamics.title: GEOPHYSICS: AI-powered Geodynamics
integrate-thermodynamics.subtitle: Mechanisms and Processes of Subduction Zone Formation
integrate-thermodynamics.content: Bridging mantle flow and thermodynamics efficiently remains a major challenge. To address this, we introduce a flexible, general, and efficient framework that integrates geodynamics with thermodynamics using machine learning.

sections.title: Research Focus
sections.content: We study the conditions and processes that lead to the formation of new subduction zones, combining field observations, laboratory experiments, and numerical modeling to understand this fundamental tectonic process.

sections.title: Analytical Approaches
sections.content: Our research employs multi-scale modeling approaches, from local stress field analysis to global geodynamic simulations, to understand the initiation and early evolution of subduction systems.

llsvp-ulvz.title: GEOPHYSICS: Deep Mantle Heterogeneities
llsvp-ulvz.subtitle: Structural Variations in Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces
llsvp-ulvz.content: The structure, morphology, and evolution of deep mantle heterogeneities hold the key to understanding the dynamic processes operating in Earth’s interior, processes that influence the geodynamo, the supercontinent cycle, and supervolcano eruptions.

sections.title: Morphological Analysis
sections.content: We analyze seismic tomography data to characterize the three-dimensional structure and morphology of LLSVPs, identifying key differences between the African and Pacific provinces.

lithium-isotope-humite.title: GEOCHEMISTRY: Tectonic Magmatism
lithium-isotope-humite.subtitle: Lithium Isotopic Signatures in Humite Group Minerals
lithium-isotope-humite.content: Tectonic magmatism is a primary window into mantle–crust interactions, recording how melts ascend, react, and reshape the lithosphere. The differentiation of these magmas generates the chemical diversity of Earth’s crust and preserves vital clues about mantle source processes and tectonic environments.

sections.title: Analytical Techniques
sections.content: We employ high-precision mass spectrometry to measure lithium isotope ratios in humite group minerals, developing new analytical protocols for small sample sizes.

images.alt: Earth from space showing atmospheric layers
images.caption: Atmospheric processes analogous to lithium isotope fractionation

mush-emplacement-bushveld.title: IGNEOUS PETROLOGY: MUSH EMPLACEMENT IN BUSHVELD
mush-emplacement-bushveld.subtitle: Magmatic Processes in the Bushveld Complex
mush-emplacement-bushveld.content: The Bushveld Complex represents one of the world's largest layered intrusions. Our research investigates the emplacement mechanisms and evolution of crystal mushes in this iconic igneous system.

sections.title: Petrological Analysis
sections.content: We study the textural and chemical characteristics of Bushveld rocks to understand the processes of mush emplacement and differentiation in large magmatic systems.

images.caption: Complex fluid dynamics similar to magmatic mush emplacement processes

zircon-coronas-fe-ti-oxides.title: GEOCHRONOLOGY: ZIRCON CORONAS AROUND FE-TI OXIDES
zircon-coronas-fe-ti-oxides.subtitle: Temporal Constraints from Zircon Corona Textures
zircon-coronas-fe-ti-oxides.content: Zircon coronas around Fe-Ti oxide minerals provide unique geochronological constraints on metamorphic and igneous processes. Our research develops new approaches to date these complex textural relationships.

sections.title: Geochronological Methods
sections.content: We use high-resolution ion microprobe techniques to date zircon coronas, providing precise temporal constraints on the formation and evolution of Fe-Ti oxide-bearing assemblages.

sections.title: Textural Analysis
sections.content: Detailed petrographic and electron microscopy studies reveal the complex relationships between zircon coronas and their host Fe-Ti oxides, informing our geochronological interpretations.
